name: Common Bladderwort

Identifying Characteristics: Leaves: paler and greener toward growing tip, finely branch divided, alternately arranged
Flowers: midsummer, yellow snapdragon-like on a stalk, may be 4-20 flowers per stalk
Other: tiny lopsided sack-like bladders (used to capture prey) attached directly to leaves, carnivorous: capture small prey such as zooplankton or small insects
Habitat: Lakes, ponds, slow-moving streams, wetland pools
Range: Native Range: Maine, much of New England, some other parts of the United States

tags: plants with finely-divided leaves on stems
